15#ifndef ISC_LOG_H
16#define ISC_LOG_H 1
17
18/*! \file isc/log.h */
19
20#include <stdbool.h>
21#include <stdio.h>
22#include <stdarg.h>
23#include <syslog.h> /* XXXDCL NT */
24
25#include <isc/formatcheck.h>
26#include <isc/lang.h>
27#include <isc/platform.h>
28#include <isc/types.h>
29
30/*@{*/
31/*!
32 * \brief Severity levels, patterned after Unix's syslog levels.
33 *
34 */
35#define ISC_LOG_DEBUG(level) (level)
36/*!
37 * #ISC_LOG_DYNAMIC can only be used for defining channels with
38 * isc_log_createchannel(), not to specify a level in isc_log_write().
39 */
40#define ISC_LOG_DYNAMIC 0
41#define ISC_LOG_INFO (-1)
42#define ISC_LOG_NOTICE (-2)
43#define ISC_LOG_WARNING (-3)
44#define ISC_LOG_ERROR (-4)
45#define ISC_LOG_CRITICAL (-5)
46/*@}*/
47
48/*@{*/
49/*!
50 * \brief Destinations.
51 */
52#define ISC_LOG_TONULL 1
53#define ISC_LOG_TOSYSLOG 2
54#define ISC_LOG_TOFILE 3
55#define ISC_LOG_TOFILEDESC 4
56/*@}*/
57
58/*@{*/
59/*%
60 * Channel flags.
61 */
62#define ISC_LOG_PRINTTIME 0x00001
63#define ISC_LOG_PRINTLEVEL 0x00002
64#define ISC_LOG_PRINTCATEGORY 0x00004
65#define ISC_LOG_PRINTMODULE 0x00008
66#define ISC_LOG_PRINTTAG 0x00010 /* tag and ":" */
67#define ISC_LOG_PRINTPREFIX 0x00020 /* tag only, no colon */
68#define ISC_LOG_PRINTALL 0x0003F
69#define ISC_LOG_BUFFERED 0x00040
70#define ISC_LOG_DEBUGONLY 0x01000
71#define ISC_LOG_OPENERR 0x08000 /* internal */
72#define ISC_LOG_ISO8601 0x10000 /* if PRINTTIME, use ISO8601 */
73#define ISC_LOG_UTC 0x20000 /* if PRINTTIME, use UTC */
74/*@}*/
75
76/*@{*/
77/*!
78 * \brief Other options.
79 *
80 * XXXDCL INFINITE doesn't yet work. Arguably it isn't needed, but
81 * since I am intend to make large number of versions work efficiently,
82 * INFINITE is going to be trivial to add to that.
83 */
84#define ISC_LOG_ROLLINFINITE (-1)
85#define ISC_LOG_ROLLNEVER (-2)
86#define ISC_LOG_MAX_VERSIONS 256
87/*@}*/
88
89/*@{*/
90/*!
91 * \brief Type of suffix used on rolled log files.
92 */
93typedef enum {
94 isc_log_rollsuffix_increment,
95 isc_log_rollsuffix_timestamp
96} isc_log_rollsuffix_t;
97/*@}*/
98
99/*!
100 * \brief Used to name the categories used by a library.
101 *
102 * An array of isc_logcategory
103 * structures names each category, and the id value is initialized by calling
104 * isc_log_registercategories.
105 */
106struct isc_logcategory {
107 const char *name;
108 unsigned int id;
109};
110
111/*%
112 * Similar to isc_logcategory, but for all the modules a library defines.
113 */
114struct isc_logmodule {
115 const char *name;
116 unsigned int id;
117};
118
119/*%
120 * The isc_logfile structure is initialized as part of an isc_logdestination
121 * before calling isc_log_createchannel().
122 *
123 * When defining an #ISC_LOG_TOFILE
124 * channel the name, versions and maximum_size should be set before calling
125 * isc_log_createchannel(). To define an #ISC_LOG_TOFILEDESC channel set only
126 * the stream before the call.
127 *
128 * Setting maximum_size to zero implies no maximum.
129 */
130typedef struct isc_logfile {
131 FILE *stream; /*%< Initialized to NULL for #ISC_LOG_TOFILE. */
132 const char *name; /*%< NULL for #ISC_LOG_TOFILEDESC. */
133 int versions; /* >= 0, #ISC_LOG_ROLLNEVER, #ISC_LOG_ROLLINFINITE. */
134 isc_log_rollsuffix_t suffix;
135 /*%
136 * stdio's ftell is standardized to return a long, which may well not
137 * be big enough for the largest file supportable by the operating
138 * system (though it is _probably_ big enough for the largest log
139 * anyone would want). st_size returned by fstat should be typedef'd
140 * to a size large enough for the largest possible file on a system.
141 */
142 isc_offset_t maximum_size;
143 bool maximum_reached; /*%< Private. */
144} isc_logfile_t;
145
146/*%
147 * Passed to isc_log_createchannel to define the attributes of either
148 * a stdio or a syslog log.
149 */
150typedef union isc_logdestination {
151 isc_logfile_t file;
152 int facility; /* XXXDCL NT */
153} isc_logdestination_t;
154
155/*@{*/
156/*%
157 * The built-in categories of libisc.
158 *
159 * Each library registering categories should provide library_LOGCATEGORY_name
160 * definitions with indexes into its isc_logcategory structure corresponding to
161 * the order of the names.
162 */
163LIBISC_EXTERNAL_DATA extern isc_logcategory_t isc_categories[];
164LIBISC_EXTERNAL_DATA extern isc_log_t *isc_lctx;
165LIBISC_EXTERNAL_DATA extern isc_logmodule_t isc_modules[];
166/*@}*/
167
168/*@{*/
169/*%
170 * Do not log directly to DEFAULT. Use another category. When in doubt,
171 * use GENERAL.
172 */
173#define ISC_LOGCATEGORY_DEFAULT (&isc_categories[0])
174#define ISC_LOGCATEGORY_GENERAL (&isc_categories[1])
175/*@}*/
176
177#define ISC_LOGMODULE_SOCKET (&isc_modules[0])
178#define ISC_LOGMODULE_TIME (&isc_modules[1])
179#define ISC_LOGMODULE_INTERFACE (&isc_modules[2])
180#define ISC_LOGMODULE_TIMER (&isc_modules[3])
181#define ISC_LOGMODULE_FILE (&isc_modules[4])
182#define ISC_LOGMODULE_OTHER (&isc_modules[5])
183
184ISC_LANG_BEGINDECLS
185
186isc_result_t
187isc_log_create(isc_mem_t *mctx, isc_log_t **lctxp, isc_logconfig_t **lcfgp);
188/*%<
189 * Establish a new logging context, with default channels.
190 *
191 * Notes:
192 *\li isc_log_create() calls isc_logconfig_create(), so see its comment
193 * below for more information.
194 *
195 * Requires:
196 *\li mctx is a valid memory context.
197 *\li lctxp is not null and *lctxp is null.
198 *\li lcfgp is null or lcfgp is not null and *lcfgp is null.
199 *
200 * Ensures:
201 *\li *lctxp will point to a valid logging context if all of the necessary
202 * memory was allocated, or NULL otherwise.
203 *\li *lcfgp will point to a valid logging configuration if all of the
204 * necessary memory was allocated, or NULL otherwise.
205 *\li On failure, no additional memory is allocated.
206 *
207 * Returns:
208 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
209 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY Resource limit: Out of memory
210 */
211
212isc_result_t
213isc_logconfig_create(isc_log_t *lctx, isc_logconfig_t **lcfgp);
214/*%<
215 * Create the data structure that holds all of the configurable information
216 * about where messages are actually supposed to be sent -- the information
217 * that could changed based on some configuration file, as opposed to the
218 * the category/module specification of isc_log_[v]write[1] that is compiled
219 * into a program, or the debug_level which is dynamic state information.
220 *
221 * Notes:
222 *\li It is necessary to specify the logging context the configuration
223 * will be used with because the number of categories and modules
224 * needs to be known in order to set the configuration. However,
225 * the configuration is not used by the logging context until the
226 * isc_logconfig_use function is called.
227 *
228 *\li The memory context used for operations that allocate memory for
229 * the configuration is that of the logging context, as specified
230 * in the isc_log_create call.
231 *
232 *\li Four default channels are established:
233 *\verbatim
234 * default_syslog
235 * - log to syslog's daemon facility #ISC_LOG_INFO or higher
236 * default_stderr
237 * - log to stderr #ISC_LOG_INFO or higher
238 * default_debug
239 * - log to stderr #ISC_LOG_DEBUG dynamically
240 * null
241 * - log nothing
242 *\endverbatim
243 *
244 * Requires:
245 *\li lctx is a valid logging context.
246 *\li lcftp is not null and *lcfgp is null.
247 *
248 * Ensures:
249 *\li *lcfgp will point to a valid logging context if all of the necessary
250 * memory was allocated, or NULL otherwise.
251 *\li On failure, no additional memory is allocated.
252 *
253 * Returns:
254 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
255 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY Resource limit: Out of memory
256 */
257
258isc_logconfig_t *
259isc_logconfig_get(isc_log_t *lctx);
260/*%<
261 * Returns a pointer to the configuration currently in use by the log context.
262 *
263 * Requires:
264 *\li lctx is a valid context.
265 *
266 * Ensures:
267 *\li The configuration pointer is non-null.
268 *
269 * Returns:
270 *\li The configuration pointer.
271 */
272
273isc_result_t
274isc_logconfig_use(isc_log_t *lctx, isc_logconfig_t *lcfg);
275/*%<
276 * Associate a new configuration with a logging context.
277 *
278 * Notes:
279 *\li This is thread safe. The logging context will lock a mutex
280 * before attempting to swap in the new configuration, and isc_log_doit
281 * (the internal function used by all of isc_log_[v]write[1]) locks
282 * the same lock for the duration of its use of the configuration.
283 *
284 * Requires:
285 *\li lctx is a valid logging context.
286 *\li lcfg is a valid logging configuration.
287 *\li lctx is the same configuration given to isc_logconfig_create
288 * when the configuration was created.
289 *
290 * Ensures:
291 *\li Future calls to isc_log_write will use the new configuration.
292 *
293 * Returns:
294 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
295 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY Resource limit: Out of memory
296 */
297
298void
299isc_log_destroy(isc_log_t **lctxp);
300/*%<
301 * Deallocate the memory associated with a logging context.
302 *
303 * Requires:
304 *\li *lctx is a valid logging context.
305 *
306 * Ensures:
307 *\li All of the memory associated with the logging context is returned
308 * to the free memory pool.
309 *
310 *\li Any open files are closed.
311 *
312 *\li The logging context is marked as invalid.
313 */
314
315void
316isc_logconfig_destroy(isc_logconfig_t **lcfgp);
317/*%<
318 * Destroy a logging configuration.
319 *
320 * Notes:
321 *\li This function cannot be used directly with the return value of
322 * isc_logconfig_get, because a logging context must always have
323 * a valid configuration associated with it.
324 *
325 * Requires:
326 *\li lcfgp is not null and *lcfgp is a valid logging configuration.
327 *\li The logging configuration is not in use by an existing logging context.
328 *
329 * Ensures:
330 *\li All memory allocated for the configuration is freed.
331 *
332 *\li The configuration is marked as invalid.
333 */
334
335void
336isc_log_registercategories(isc_log_t *lctx, isc_logcategory_t categories[]);
337/*%<
338 * Identify logging categories a library will use.
339 *
340 * Notes:
341 *\li A category should only be registered once, but no mechanism enforces
342 * this rule.
343 *
344 *\li The end of the categories array is identified by a NULL name.
345 *
346 *\li Because the name is used by #ISC_LOG_PRINTCATEGORY, it should not
347 * be altered or destroyed after isc_log_registercategories().
348 *
349 *\li Because each element of the categories array is used by
350 * isc_log_categorybyname, it should not be altered or destroyed
351 * after registration.
352 *
353 *\li The value of the id integer in each structure is overwritten
354 * by this function, and so id need not be initialized to any particular
355 * value prior to the function call.
356 *
357 *\li A subsequent call to isc_log_registercategories with the same
358 * logging context (but new categories) will cause the last
359 * element of the categories array from the prior call to have
360 * its "name" member changed from NULL to point to the new
361 * categories array, and its "id" member set to UINT_MAX.
362 *
363 * Requires:
364 *\li lctx is a valid logging context.
365 *\li categories != NULL.
366 *\li categories[0].name != NULL.
367 *
368 * Ensures:
369 * \li There are references to each category in the logging context,
370 * so they can be used with isc_log_usechannel() and isc_log_write().
371 */
372
373void
374isc_log_registermodules(isc_log_t *lctx, isc_logmodule_t modules[]);
375/*%<
376 * Identify logging categories a library will use.
377 *
378 * Notes:
379 *\li A module should only be registered once, but no mechanism enforces
380 * this rule.
381 *
382 *\li The end of the modules array is identified by a NULL name.
383 *
384 *\li Because the name is used by #ISC_LOG_PRINTMODULE, it should not
385 * be altered or destroyed after isc_log_registermodules().
386 *
387 *\li Because each element of the modules array is used by
388 * isc_log_modulebyname, it should not be altered or destroyed
389 * after registration.
390 *
391 *\li The value of the id integer in each structure is overwritten
392 * by this function, and so id need not be initialized to any particular
393 * value prior to the function call.
394 *
395 *\li A subsequent call to isc_log_registermodules with the same
396 * logging context (but new modules) will cause the last
397 * element of the modules array from the prior call to have
398 * its "name" member changed from NULL to point to the new
399 * modules array, and its "id" member set to UINT_MAX.
400 *
401 * Requires:
402 *\li lctx is a valid logging context.
403 *\li modules != NULL.
404 *\li modules[0].name != NULL;
405 *
406 * Ensures:
407 *\li Each module has a reference in the logging context, so they can be
408 * used with isc_log_usechannel() and isc_log_write().
409 */
410
411isc_result_t
412isc_log_createchannel(isc_logconfig_t *lcfg, const char *name,
413 unsigned int type, int level,
414 const isc_logdestination_t *destination,
415 unsigned int flags);
416/*%<
417 * Specify the parameters of a logging channel.
418 *
419 * Notes:
420 *\li The name argument is copied to memory in the logging context, so
421 * it can be altered or destroyed after isc_log_createchannel().
422 *
423 *\li Defining a very large number of channels will have a performance
424 * impact on isc_log_usechannel(), since the names are searched
425 * linearly until a match is made. This same issue does not affect
426 * isc_log_write, however.
427 *
428 *\li Channel names can be redefined; this is primarily useful for programs
429 * that want their own definition of default_syslog, default_debug
430 * and default_stderr.
431 *
432 *\li Any channel that is redefined will not affect logging that was
433 * already directed to its original definition, _except_ for the
434 * default_stderr channel. This case is handled specially so that
435 * the default logging category can be changed by redefining
436 * default_stderr. (XXXDCL Though now that I think of it, the default
437 * logging category can be changed with only one additional function
438 * call by defining a new channel and then calling isc_log_usechannel()
439 * for #ISC_LOGCATEGORY_DEFAULT.)
440 *
441 *\li Specifying #ISC_LOG_PRINTTIME or #ISC_LOG_PRINTTAG for syslog is
442 * allowed, but probably not what you wanted to do.
443 *
444 * #ISC_LOG_DEBUGONLY will mark the channel as usable only when the
445 * debug level of the logging context (see isc_log_setdebuglevel)
446 * is non-zero.
447 *
448 * Requires:
449 *\li lcfg is a valid logging configuration.
450 *
451 *\li name is not NULL.
452 *
453 *\li type is #ISC_LOG_TOSYSLOG, #ISC_LOG_TOFILE, #ISC_LOG_TOFILEDESC or
454 * #ISC_LOG_TONULL.
455 *
456 *\li destination is not NULL unless type is #ISC_LOG_TONULL.
457 *
458 *\li level is >= #ISC_LOG_CRITICAL (the most negative logging level).
459 *
460 *\li flags does not include any bits aside from the ISC_LOG_PRINT* bits,
461 * #ISC_LOG_DEBUGONLY or #ISC_LOG_BUFFERED.
462 *
463 * Ensures:
464 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
465 * A channel with the given name is usable with
466 * isc_log_usechannel().
467 *
468 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY or #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
469 * No additional memory is being used by the logging context.
470 * Any channel that previously existed with the given name
471 * is not redefined.
472 *
473 * Returns:
474 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
475 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY Resource limit: Out of memory
476 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED type was out of range and REQUIRE()
477 * was disabled.
478 */
479
480isc_result_t
481isc_log_usechannel(isc_logconfig_t *lcfg, const char *name,
482 const isc_logcategory_t *category,
483 const isc_logmodule_t *module);
484/*%<
485 * Associate a named logging channel with a category and module that
486 * will use it.
487 *
488 * Notes:
489 *\li The name is searched for linearly in the set of known channel names
490 * until a match is found. (Note the performance impact of a very large
491 * number of named channels.) When multiple channels of the same
492 * name are defined, the most recent definition is found.
493 *
494 *\li Specifying a very large number of channels for a category will have
495 * a moderate impact on performance in isc_log_write(), as each
496 * call looks up the category for the start of a linked list, which
497 * it follows all the way to the end to find matching modules. The
498 * test for matching modules is integral, though.
499 *
500 *\li If category is NULL, then the channel is associated with the indicated
501 * module for all known categories (including the "default" category).
502 *
503 *\li If module is NULL, then the channel is associated with every module
504 * that uses that category.
505 *
506 *\li Passing both category and module as NULL would make every log message
507 * use the indicated channel.
508 *
509 * \li Specifying a channel that is #ISC_LOG_TONULL for a category/module pair
510 * has no effect on any other channels associated with that pair,
511 * regardless of ordering. Thus you cannot use it to "mask out" one
512 * category/module pair when you have specified some other channel that
513 * is also used by that category/module pair.
514 *
515 * Requires:
516 *\li lcfg is a valid logging configuration.
517 *
518 *\li category is NULL or has an id that is in the range of known ids.
519 *
520 * module is NULL or has an id that is in the range of known ids.
521 *
522 * Ensures:
523 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
524 * The channel will be used by the indicated category/module
525 * arguments.
526 *
527 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY
528 * If assignment for a specific category has been requested,
529 * the channel has not been associated with the indicated
530 * category/module arguments and no additional memory is
531 * used by the logging context.
532 * If assignment for all categories has been requested
533 * then _some_ may have succeeded (starting with category
534 * "default" and progressing through the order of categories
535 * passed to isc_log_registercategories()) and additional memory
536 * is being used by whatever assignments succeeded.
537 *
538 * Returns:
539 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
540 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY Resource limit: Out of memory
541 */
542
543/* Attention: next four comments PRECEED code */
544/*!
545 * \brief
546 * Write a message to the log channels.
547 *
548 * Notes:
549 *\li lctx can be NULL; this is allowed so that programs which use
550 * libraries that use the ISC logging system are not required to
551 * also use it.
552 *
553 *\li The format argument is a printf(3) string, with additional arguments
554 * as necessary.
555 *
556 * Requires:
557 *\li lctx is a valid logging context.
558 *
559 *\li The category and module arguments must have ids that are in the
560 * range of known ids, as established by isc_log_registercategories()
561 * and isc_log_registermodules().
562 *
563 *\li level != #ISC_LOG_DYNAMIC. ISC_LOG_DYNAMIC is used only to define
564 * channels, and explicit debugging level must be identified for
565 * isc_log_write() via ISC_LOG_DEBUG(level).
566 *
567 *\li format != NULL.
568 *
569 * Ensures:
570 *\li The log message is written to every channel associated with the
571 * indicated category/module pair.
572 *
573 * Returns:
574 *\li Nothing. Failure to log a message is not construed as a
575 * meaningful error.
576 */
577void
578isc_log_write(isc_log_t *lctx, isc_logcategory_t *category,
579 isc_logmodule_t *module, int level,
580 const char *format, ...)
581
582ISC_FORMAT_PRINTF(5, 6);
583
584/*%
585 * Write a message to the log channels.
586 *
587 * Notes:
588 *\li lctx can be NULL; this is allowed so that programs which use
589 * libraries that use the ISC logging system are not required to
590 * also use it.
591 *
592 *\li The format argument is a printf(3) string, with additional arguments
593 * as necessary.
594 *
595 * Requires:
596 *\li lctx is a valid logging context.
597 *
598 *\li The category and module arguments must have ids that are in the
599 * range of known ids, as established by isc_log_registercategories()
600 * and isc_log_registermodules().
601 *
602 *\li level != #ISC_LOG_DYNAMIC. ISC_LOG_DYNAMIC is used only to define
603 * channels, and explicit debugging level must be identified for
604 * isc_log_write() via ISC_LOG_DEBUG(level).
605 *
606 *\li format != NULL.
607 *
608 * Ensures:
609 *\li The log message is written to every channel associated with the
610 * indicated category/module pair.
611 *
612 * Returns:
613 *\li Nothing. Failure to log a message is not construed as a
614 * meaningful error.
615 */
616void
617isc_log_vwrite(isc_log_t *lctx, isc_logcategory_t *category,
618 isc_logmodule_t *module, int level,
619 const char *format, va_list args)
620
621ISC_FORMAT_PRINTF(5, 0);
622
623/*%
624 * Write a message to the log channels, pruning duplicates that occur within
625 * a configurable amount of seconds (see isc_log_[sg]etduplicateinterval).
626 * This function is otherwise identical to isc_log_write().
627 */
628void
629isc_log_write1(isc_log_t *lctx, isc_logcategory_t *category,
630 isc_logmodule_t *module, int level, const char *format, ...)
631
632ISC_FORMAT_PRINTF(5, 6);
633
634/*%
635 * Write a message to the log channels, pruning duplicates that occur within
636 * a configurable amount of seconds (see isc_log_[sg]etduplicateinterval).
637 * This function is otherwise identical to isc_log_vwrite().
638 */
639void
640isc_log_vwrite1(isc_log_t *lctx, isc_logcategory_t *category,
641 isc_logmodule_t *module, int level, const char *format,
642 va_list args)
643
644ISC_FORMAT_PRINTF(5, 0);
645
646void
647isc_log_setdebuglevel(isc_log_t *lctx, unsigned int level);
648/*%<
649 * Set the debugging level used for logging.
650 *
651 * Notes:
652 *\li Setting the debugging level to 0 disables debugging log messages.
653 *
654 * Requires:
655 *\li lctx is a valid logging context.
656 *
657 * Ensures:
658 *\li The debugging level is set to the requested value.
659 */
660
661unsigned int
662isc_log_getdebuglevel(isc_log_t *lctx);
663/*%<
664 * Get the current debugging level.
665 *
666 * Notes:
667 *\li This is provided so that a program can have a notion of
668 * "increment debugging level" or "decrement debugging level"
669 * without needing to keep track of what the current level is.
670 *
671 *\li A return value of 0 indicates that debugging messages are disabled.
672 *
673 * Requires:
674 *\li lctx is a valid logging context.
675 *
676 * Ensures:
677 *\li The current logging debugging level is returned.
678 */
679
680bool
681isc_log_wouldlog(isc_log_t *lctx, int level);
682/*%<
683 * Determine whether logging something to 'lctx' at 'level' would
684 * actually cause something to be logged somewhere.
685 *
686 * If #false is returned, it is guaranteed that nothing would
687 * be logged, allowing the caller to omit unnecessary
688 * isc_log_write() calls and possible message preformatting.
689 */
690
691void
692isc_log_setduplicateinterval(isc_logconfig_t *lcfg, unsigned int interval);
693/*%<
694 * Set the interval over which duplicate log messages will be ignored
695 * by isc_log_[v]write1(), in seconds.
696 *
697 * Notes:
698 *\li Increasing the duplicate interval from X to Y will not necessarily
699 * filter out duplicates of messages logged in Y - X seconds since the
700 * increase. (Example: Message1 is logged at midnight. Message2
701 * is logged at 00:01:00, when the interval is only 30 seconds, causing
702 * Message1 to be expired from the log message history. Then the interval
703 * is increased to 3000 (five minutes) and at 00:04:00 Message1 is logged
704 * again. It will appear the second time even though less than five
705 * passed since the first occurrence.
706 *
707 * Requires:
708 *\li lctx is a valid logging context.
709 */
710
711unsigned int
712isc_log_getduplicateinterval(isc_logconfig_t *lcfg);
713/*%<
714 * Get the current duplicate filtering interval.
715 *
716 * Requires:
717 *\li lctx is a valid logging context.
718 *
719 * Returns:
720 *\li The current duplicate filtering interval.
721 */
722
723isc_result_t
724isc_log_settag(isc_logconfig_t *lcfg, const char *tag);
725/*%<
726 * Set the program name or other identifier for #ISC_LOG_PRINTTAG.
727 *
728 * Requires:
729 *\li lcfg is a valid logging configuration.
730 *
731 * Notes:
732 *\li If this function has not set the tag to a non-NULL, non-empty value,
733 * then the #ISC_LOG_PRINTTAG channel flag will not print anything.
734 * Unlike some implementations of syslog on Unix systems, you *must* set
735 * the tag in order to get it logged. It is not implicitly derived from
736 * the program name (which is pretty impossible to infer portably).
737 *
738 *\li Setting the tag to NULL or the empty string will also cause the
739 * #ISC_LOG_PRINTTAG channel flag to not print anything. If tag equals the
740 * empty string, calls to isc_log_gettag will return NULL.
741 *
742 * Returns:
743 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
744 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY Resource Limit: Out of memory
745 *
746 * XXXDCL when creating a new isc_logconfig_t, it might be nice if the tag
747 * of the currently active isc_logconfig_t was inherited. this does not
748 * currently happen.
749 */
750
751char *
752isc_log_gettag(isc_logconfig_t *lcfg);
753/*%<
754 * Get the current identifier printed with #ISC_LOG_PRINTTAG.
755 *
756 * Requires:
757 *\li lcfg is a valid logging configuration.
758 *
759 * Notes:
760 *\li Since isc_log_settag() will not associate a zero-length string
761 * with the logging configuration, attempts to do so will cause
762 * this function to return NULL. However, a determined programmer
763 * will observe that (currently) a tag of length greater than zero
764 * could be set, and then modified to be zero length.
765 *
766 * Returns:
767 *\li A pointer to the current identifier, or NULL if none has been set.
768 */
769
770void
771isc_log_opensyslog(const char *tag, int options, int facility);
772/*%<
773 * Initialize syslog logging.
774 *
775 * Notes:
776 *\li XXXDCL NT
777 * This is currently equivalent to openlog(), but is not going to remain
778 * that way. In the meantime, the arguments are all identical to
779 * those used by openlog(3), as follows:
780 *
781 * \code
782 * tag: The string to use in the position of the program
783 * name in syslog messages. Most (all?) syslogs
784 * will use basename(argv[0]) if tag is NULL.
785 *
786 * options: LOG_CONS, LOG_PID, LOG_NDELAY ... whatever your
787 * syslog supports.
788 *
789 * facility: The default syslog facility. This is irrelevant
790 * since isc_log_write will ALWAYS use the channel's
791 * declared facility.
792 * \endcode
793 *
794 *\li Zero effort has been made (yet) to accommodate systems with openlog()
795 * that only takes two arguments, or to identify valid syslog
796 * facilities or options for any given architecture.
797 *
798 *\li It is necessary to call isc_log_opensyslog() to initialize
799 * syslogging on machines which do not support network connections to
800 * syslogd because they require a Unix domain socket to be used. Since
801 * this is a chore to determine at run-time, it is suggested that it
802 * always be called by programs using the ISC logging system.
803 *
804 * Requires:
805 *\li Nothing.
806 *
807 * Ensures:
808 *\li openlog() is called to initialize the syslog system.
809 */
810
811void
812isc_log_closefilelogs(isc_log_t *lctx);
813/*%<
814 * Close all open files used by #ISC_LOG_TOFILE channels.
815 *
816 * Notes:
817 *\li This function is provided for programs that want to use their own
818 * log rolling mechanism rather than the one provided internally.
819 * For example, a program that wanted to keep daily logs would define
820 * a channel which used #ISC_LOG_ROLLNEVER, then once a day would
821 * rename the log file and call isc_log_closefilelogs().
822 *
823 *\li #ISC_LOG_TOFILEDESC channels are unaffected.
824 *
825 * Requires:
826 *\li lctx is a valid context.
827 *
828 * Ensures:
829 *\li The open files are closed and will be reopened when they are
830 * next needed.
831 */
832
833isc_logcategory_t *
834isc_log_categorybyname(isc_log_t *lctx, const char *name);
835/*%<
836 * Find a category by its name.
837 *
838 * Notes:
839 *\li The string name of a category is not required to be unique.
840 *
841 * Requires:
842 *\li lctx is a valid context.
843 *\li name is not NULL.
844 *
845 * Returns:
846 *\li A pointer to the _first_ isc_logcategory_t structure used by "name".
847 *
848 *\li NULL if no category exists by that name.
849 */
850
851isc_logmodule_t *
852isc_log_modulebyname(isc_log_t *lctx, const char *name);
853/*%<
854 * Find a module by its name.
855 *
856 * Notes:
857 *\li The string name of a module is not required to be unique.
858 *
859 * Requires:
860 *\li lctx is a valid context.
861 *\li name is not NULL.
862 *
863 * Returns:
864 *\li A pointer to the _first_ isc_logmodule_t structure used by "name".
865 *
866 *\li NULL if no module exists by that name.
867 */
868
869void
870isc_log_setcontext(isc_log_t *lctx);
871/*%<
872 * Sets the context used by the libisc for logging.
873 *
874 * Requires:
875 *\li lctx be a valid context.
876 */
877
878isc_result_t
879isc_logfile_roll(isc_logfile_t *file);
880/*%<
881 * Roll a logfile.
882 *
883 * Requires:
884 *\li file is not NULL.
885 */

889#endif /* ISC_LOG_H */
